turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: In the petition before the Commission.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: None of that is here.

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: It is not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It is in the record.

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: It is in the joint appendix of the D.C. Circuit.
We were asked to keep down the record.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Isn't it in the record that has been lodged here, somewhere?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It is not in the printed--

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: It is not in the joint appendix.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --It is in the record lodged here, isn't it?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: It's in the record.
The record would include, I assume, the joint appendix of the D.C. Circuit, and we were asked to keep the record down.
The Commission did not... well, I don't want to go into the Joint appendix problems, but I apologize for not having--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Firestone, do you think it is crystal clear that this television station and the programming it presents is
"a program or activity receiving federal financial assistance. "
under the terms of 504--

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --and that it would have no defense to an action, say, if the appropriate agency brought it in court?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, and in fact this has been held by everyone who has looked at.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What do you mean, held by everyone?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Well, the District Court--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Are some of them judges?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: --Yes, the District Court in Los Angeles held that they were subject to 504.
The Department of Health, Education, and Welfare held that they were subject to 504.

And I would like to point out that this licensee is... receives assistance not only from the Department of Education, the Department of Commerce, the National Endowment for the Arts, the National Endowment for the Humanities, the U.S. Information Administration, but also the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the Public Broadcasting Service, and particularly the Corporation for Public Broadcasting is... they float through federal funds to the licensee, but they do not... they are not a federal agency.
They don't have the enforcement power.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Didn't the station make some defense in the Court of Appeals that it was not subject to this provision, that it had a statutory exemption from program control or something to that effect?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Well, the Court of Appeals disposed of it in a footnote.
Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, if we get back to your contention that all these things ought to be originally thrashed out before the FCC, does that really make much sense, if it is deciding a fairly complicated question of... wouldn't you want the agency charged with the statutory mandate whose administrative interpretation would be entitled to considerable weight to make those kind of determinations in the first place?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Well, I don't see how the fact that the licensee got $5 million in federal money in 1977, and how they have gotten something like 30 percent of their money from federal subsidies can be a difficult question as to whether or not they are subject to 504.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Could you have just gone into a district court somewhere and sought to enjoin or to get an injunction against the station for violations of 504?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Yes, there was an action.
There was such an action.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, there was such an action.
Did you win?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: No, the... well--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What was the result of the action?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: --The result was that the court found that they couldn't... that there was no standard by any of these funding agencies.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Didn't they say you should go to the funding agency, or not?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: It was the... actually, the licensee in that decision, and that is, I think, at Page 149 of the joint appendix that you have, argued that there was primary jurisdiction in the FCC.
That is where they told... that is what they were telling the court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Did you lose, or what happened?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: It is on appeal in the Ninth Circuit.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you lost in the district court on the grounds that that was the wrong place to go?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: No, no.
The district court found that the... they dismissed the licensee because there was no standards for the licensee to comply with, and they then issued an order for the--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No standards issued by the funding agency.

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: --By the funding agencies, and they included the Federal Communications Commission.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now, this Court has said countless times, and other courts have, that these regulatory agencies have broad, very broad discretion as to what they will weigh and take into account.

Now, if an agency has exercised that discretion and come up with what someone regards as a wrong decision, isn't the review of that decision limited to an abuse of discretion, not a matter of a Court of Appeals deciding that it should have been done some other way?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, and that's exactly what happened in this case.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And you suggest there is an abuse of discretion here on the part of the agency?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Yes.

Yes, there was an abuse of discretion by failing to consider a relevant factor, making the consideration of a law that is clearly relevant to communications, to the Communications Act... we are talking about inclusion of a segment... a minority segment of the audience, something that really goes to the underlying purposes of the Communications Act.
In fact, if you--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: An abuse of discretion on the Commission's part because it decided to defer to an agency which has a life or death control over a public television station, life or death control by virtue of the grants.

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: --Well, the agencies that they deferred to do not have life and death control.
The life or death control is the Commission's, and in fact--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Don't you think the grants have a lot to do... perhaps life and death isn't quite it, but they can shut off the supply of blood, can't they?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: --They can, and that would be an extreme remedy which we frankly would not like to see, but the... because we would like to see public... we don't want to hurt public broadcasting.
We are trying to get more service, not less.
In other words, the remedy... we were faced there with a remedy that is an unsatisfactory remedy to everyone.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But the grant agency doesn't always just inflict a death blow right away.
They inform the grantee or the prospective grantee that if they don't do certain things, then their grant will be cut off.

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Isn't that the real control over this problem?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: No, Your Honor, it isn't, quite honestly.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, 504, though, isn't a commerce power regulation.
It's spending power, isn't it?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Yes, but it is still aimed at--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And it only affects people who get federal money.

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: --That's right, which is this licensee.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It is not a general regulation that people who communicate over the airways that are granted, that are licensed through a public authority are subject to this regulation.
It is just people who get money.

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What kind of an agency, or what kind of a licensee do we have here?
Do we have one who got money?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, then--

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: A licensee who received money from the federal government.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: However, some of the--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And if they don't play ball according to the views of that agency, they aren't going to get any more money.
Isn't that the prospect?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: --Perhaps that would be the extreme repercussion.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Isn't that the statutory scheme?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Your Honor, and I would really like to go to the statutory scheme, which contemplates not only that these factors would be enforced at the individual funding agencies, and by the way, they get most of their funds from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which cannot in fact enforce this statute.
They also get a lot of their equipment from the Department of Commerce through facilities grants, and how do you enforce that after you have given them the facilities?
I mean, there are some real problems with the enforcement aspect here.
But in the end, it is really the FCC that must look at the overall operation of the station.

The fact that this licensee is subject to this law is simply... I mean, is very importantly a factor to be taken into account when they look at whether or not a licensee is law abiding, and look at the character of the licensee, look at the operation of the station, look at the intent of Congress.
Congress, at the time that they passed the Rehabilitation Act, the FCC was considering allegations of discrimination.
They were considering equal employment allegations.
They were considering programming allegations.
Even though these could have been affected by going to an agency.
Let me give an example.

Let's say that in Jackson, Mississippi, there is a licensee who always excluded blacks from the screen, and they got money from the federal government through... let's say they are a public licensee and they got their equipment, say, from the government.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Wasn't that issue settled in United Church of Christ against WLBT?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: That's right, and the Commission had an obligation to--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That was a clear case of discrimination on the basis of race, was it not?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: --But the Commission is saying that if there is another agency... that's exactly what this case is about.
If there is another agency who can enforce this law, because the law would be Title VI, that would be a violation of Title VI, if there is another agency that can enforce that, we won't look at it.
In that case, the Commission... the analogy would be here, we are not going to look at it until another agency decides whether or not there is a violation.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But in the United Church of Christ case, it was 50 or 60 percent of the audience that was being discriminated against.
What percentage of the audience total is involved here?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Your Honor, the percentage is in single figures, I think.
The hearing impaired may be 5 percent.
The severely hearing impaired may be 5 percent.
Somewhere between... around 5 to 7 percent or so.
But that I don't think is the proper criterion in this case to consider.
The fact is that Congress intended to protect this class of people.

It intended that licensees who receive federal money open up, lower their barriers to the provision of the programming for these people, and the FCC would be the... really the appropriate place to exert their expertise.

I mean, this... we are talking about an educational, informational, vital part of this country which is, for better or worse, television, and it is considered maybe the second most influential institution in the United States, and we are now in 1982, and there are... the Commission has still not looked at this question as to whether or not a licensee is complying or even serving the purposes of the Communications Act... I mean, of the Rehabilitation Act.

I think that Congress intended in the legislative history of Section 504 that this would be a broad policy, and I would like to bring the Court to the cases where the Court has said that the FCC cannot ignore a relevant statute.

Let me give you an example of one that the Commission cites in its EEO rules, where the National Labor Relations Board wanted to reinstate some employees on a ship who had struck and in fact the court found that this was a violation of the mutiny, that the actual strike happened to be a violation of the mutiny laws, and they said, you cannot apply the National Labor Relations Act without considering other relevant statutes to this matter.

There is no question that Congress intended this law to be a broad policy to include the deaf, include the disabled, and what the Commission is saying, and I think quite clearly, today, is, this is not something that we must take into account when we have... make our independent public interest standard, and there are plenty of cases, including the United Church of Christ case, which say that the Commission must look at the facts of that case.
Remeber, in that case they tried to defer the question of the discrimination.
It is a very similar situation.
Let's say that the Commission in that case said, well, this is something for another agency to decide, we won't decide it, and they waited and waited, and another agency didn't come forward.

Or the NPC case, which proposes or suggests... this is the U.S. Supreme Court case... that because the licensee might be in violation of the antitrust laws, which of course the Justice Department primarily enforces, does not mean that the Commission must not take the policies of the antitrust laws into account in the Communications Act.
They have tried to distinguish the antitrust laws by saying, well, this is so clearly related to the Communications Act.
There is no question that the provision of service to minority groups is vitally important to the--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: In that case, the Commission should take into consideration the antitrust laws on its own motion?
It wasn't forced to by a Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: --They weren't, but there are other cases where Courts of Appeals have required, and the Supreme Court, required that they take into account the... such as the Southern Steamship case that I was referring to a minute ago.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: That was the National Labor Relations Board, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Yes, but the principle is the same.
The principle is that where there is a... and the NAACP case is another example.
Now, there, the NAACP adopted a rule, but the point is that where there is a clearly relevant statute, that what is happening here is that Congress... that the FCC is ignoring Congressional policy.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you say that the FCC must take into account any clearly defined federal policy expressed in a statute?
Every one.

And that the FCC is not free to say in administering the public interest standard that we are going to exclude from our considerations of the public interest standard Statute A, B, and C, but include them in D, E, and F.
You say that is just wrong?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: It is wrong if the statute that they are excluding relates to the underlying values of the Communications Act.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, may they exclude any statute that has some relevance to the--

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: May they exclude any statute that has relevance?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --from consideration of the public interest?
They say, we are in charge of administering the public interest standard, here is a statute we think is too tangential to be considered.

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: They... I would first preface this by saying that that is... this case... that is broader than what this case holds, and it is broader than the NAACP versus Federal Power Commission.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but surely the Court of Appeals imposed ingredients of the public interest that the Communcations Commission rejected.
They are saying, you must consider part of the public interest, A, B, and C, even though you don't want to.

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Because the Commission abused its discretion by failing to consider this relevant factor which they agree is relevant.

The Commission itself said, well, we will take this into account at a later time, perhaps, although they didn't condition... they didn't do the formal action that they needed to do in order to take that into account, but where there is a relevant statute, certainly they must consider... this is... says the same where the court says, okay, when we look over... the reviewing standard is arbitrary, capricious, abuse of standard, or abiding by law, and part of that discussion and search, scrutiny by the court is whether or not they considered all relevant factors.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, suppose the Commission had undertaken a rulemaking proceeding about this subject, and the submissions were so confusing and the technology in such a state of flux that they declined to issue any rule, that it just wasn't timely to issue a rule right now, and then the next day this submission is made, that the license should be denied because of failure to live up to 504.
Can't the Commission say, awfully sorry, but it just isn't... now is just not the time to do that?

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Well, I think what they would have to do is at least look at the allegations.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, they did look at the allegations, and they said, we don't want to have another hearing, we just decided that it isn't time to have a decision.

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: No, what they did was, they looked at those allegations in consideration of another factor.
In other words, they looked at-it without taking into account what the Congressional policy was with respect to the deaf.

They said, okay, we are not going to look at the programming scheduling, but they didn't look at the programming scheduling and the decision of the licensee not to carry this programming, for example, with the idea in mind of Congress intending that the deaf... that the recipients of federal financial assistance make reasonable accommodations to serve the disabled.

That was plain and simple what happened here, was ignoring of federal policy and a clearly relevant statute to the public interest standard, and the Commission's failure to judge management of discrimination.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Your time has expired now, counsel.

turn.speaker: charles_m_firestone
turn.label: Mr. Charles M. Firestone
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Czarra.

section.heading: Rebuttal of Edgar F. Czarra, Jr.

turn.speaker: edgar_f_czarra_jr
turn.label: Mr. Edgar F. Czarra, Jr.
turn.text: Justice Stevens, the Respondents here asked the FCC to deny KCET's license because it was not broadcasting with open captions all of its programs.
That was their complaint.
That was the relief that they sought.
Now, as far as what--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Does the record tell us whether any station uses captioning in all its programs?

turn.speaker: edgar_f_czarra_jr
turn.label: Mr. Edgar F. Czarra, Jr.
turn.text: --The record, I think, does not show that, Your Honor, but the point is, Justice White, that KCET did everything that the FCC had said in its policy statements it was going to require.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Your colleague denied that.

turn.speaker: edgar_f_czarra_jr
turn.label: Mr. Edgar F. Czarra, Jr.
turn.text: He is incorrect.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is that in the record?

turn.speaker: edgar_f_czarra_jr
turn.label: Mr. Edgar F. Czarra, Jr.
turn.text: It is in the record.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That it complied with everything the FCC had suggested stations ought to do?

turn.speaker: edgar_f_czarra_jr
turn.label: Mr. Edgar F. Czarra, Jr.
turn.text: The only thing the FCC said it was going to require stations to do--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, suggest, suggest.

turn.speaker: edgar_f_czarra_jr
turn.label: Mr. Edgar F. Czarra, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, all right.
First we will take require.
Was emergency messages.
There is not an allegation anywhere that KCET failed to do that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: How about suggest?

turn.speaker: edgar_f_czarra_jr
turn.label: Mr. Edgar F. Czarra, Jr.
turn.text: The suggestions were that the faces of newscasters be present on the screen, that scores of games be given visually.
KCET didn't broadcast any games.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You mean, not even scores?

turn.speaker: edgar_f_czarra_jr
turn.label: Mr. Edgar F. Czarra, Jr.
turn.text: I think not.
They are supposed to be educational.
0 [Generallaughter.]

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They would violate their license if they broadcast one, I suppose.

turn.speaker: edgar_f_czarra_jr
turn.label: Mr. Edgar F. Czarra, Jr.
turn.text: No, the question, I guess, is, would they violate their license if they didn't broadcast one.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If they didn't, okay.

turn.speaker: edgar_f_czarra_jr
turn.label: Mr. Edgar F. Czarra, Jr.
turn.text: After a day and a half of trial in federal district court in California, the judge dismissed the complaint against KCET, the complaint of discrimination, on the ground that there had been no proof of discrimination.
We didn't even have to put on our defense.
And... Thank you.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you can certainly finish your--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Finish your sentence.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --Finish your answer to my question.

turn.speaker: edgar_f_czarra_jr
turn.label: Mr. Edgar F. Czarra, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I was going to another point.
I had finished that one.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, not quite.
0 [Generallaughter.]

turn.speaker: edgar_f_czarra_jr
turn.label: Mr. Edgar F. Czarra, Jr.
turn.text: Wonderful.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Did the court find, or has anybody found, or is it just your assertion, that the station had lived up to every suggestion that the FCC had made about taking care of the handicapped?

turn.speaker: edgar_f_czarra_jr
turn.label: Mr. Edgar F. Czarra, Jr.
turn.text: The only express suggestions were the ones that I enumerated, emergency bulletins, focusing on the face of people so that lipreading would be permissible, and giving scores in writing.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
